docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I agree wholeheartedly with ''We Still Can't Stop the Biological Clock,'' by Zev Rosenwaks (Op-Ed, June 24). As a veteran of five years of infertility treatments, and as a professor of embryology, I know how very real a biological clock can be.
docs.abstract: Prof Rachel Fink letter on Zev Rosenwaks's June 24 article urges aging women unable to restore their fertility to consider adoption

docs.lead_paragraph: The struggle over prescription drug benefits for the elderly, now center stage in the House, is not simply between Democrats and Republicans, liberals and conservatives. It has also driven a wedge between two of the biggest, most influential lobbies in Washington: the Health Insurance Association of America and the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America. For months now, the pharmaceutical industry has been arguing -- on Capitol Hill and beyond, in an intensive advertising campaign -- that any new prescription drug benefit for the elderly must be provided through the private sector, not the traditional Medicare program.

headline.main: Fight Over Prescription Drug Benefits for Elderly Creates Unlikely Enemies

docs.abstract: Struggle over prescription drug benefits for elderly has driven wedge between two of biggest, most influential lobbies in Washington: Health Insurance Assn of America and Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America; pharmaceutical industry argues that any new prescription drug benefit for elderly must be provided through private sector, not traditional Medicare program; industry said to fear that direct government involvement will lead to government pressure on drug industry prices; insurance industry is warning that private-sector solution would be difficult to achieve, and that even with federal subsidies, private companies would have hard time offering affordable product and making profit in market where drug prices keep rising and sickest elderly people are most likley to buy the coverage (M)
docs.snippet: The struggle over prescription drug benefits for the elderly, now center stage in the House, is not simply between Democrats and Republicans, liberals and conservatives. It has also driven a wedge between two of the biggest, most influential lobbies...

docs.lead_paragraph: SOME 13 million Americans suffer from thyroid disorders, most of them women, including Barbara Bush, Tipper Gore and the Olympic track star Gail Devers. But more than half don't know it. Thyroid disorders, experts say, are among the most undiagnosed and misdiagnosed problems in the United States. Doctors generally don't examine the thyroid. Disorders come on slowly, and the symptoms can be ambiguous.

headline.main: Your Thyroid May Be Talking, but Is the Doctor Listening?

docs.abstract: Some 13 million Americans suffer from thyroid disorders, most of them women, but more than half do not know it; thyroid disorders are widely undiagnosed and misdiagnosed because symptoms can be ambiguous and doctors do not make simple blood test, particularly under managed care; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ETHELYN BOWERS had a master's degree, an executive-level job and a husband who was a doctor with access to some of the best medical care available. But her accomplishments and connections seemed to make little difference when she endured the premature births and subsequent deaths of three babies, two of whom were in a set of triplets. A competitive businesswoman who is immersed in her career and the hectic schedules of her surviving children, now 9 and 11, Ms. Bowers is candid about her losses but does not dwell on their possible causes. ''I just chalked it up to bad luck, mainly,'' said Ms. Bowers, a sales director for Lucent Technologies who lives with her family in Livingston, N.J.

headline.main: A Racial Gap in Infant Deaths, and a Search for Reasons

docs.abstract: Growing field of research is struggling to explain a persistent racial gap in US infant mortality rates; even as overall rate improves, to a record low national average of 7.2 deaths per 1,000 live births, the disparity between whites and blacks has grown, from 2 to nearly 2.4 times the number of infant deaths; especially troubling is evidence that this is not simply because of poverty; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: OF all the zingers uttered by my obstetrician, Alan DeCherney (known for his great delivery, in every sense of the word), the most memorable was when I told him that I thought I wanted to squat while giving birth. ''And what am I supposed to do?'' he demanded. ''Get down on the floor in a raincoat?'' The year was 1987. The hospital was Yale-New Haven. Note that I said hospital. As an elderly primagravida (loosely translated, a first-time mom-to-be who will be receiving mail from the AARP by the time her child is in middle school), my concern was not so much to experience childbirth as to survive it.

headline.main: The Baby and the Bathwater: Birth Methods Then and Now

docs.abstract: Elin Schoen Brockman article on trends in birthing methods, from natural childbirth and water immersion to booking inductions and Caesarians months ahead of time; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: LOURDES DAVILA'S recent meeting with teachers at Mahan Elementary School in Norwich was fairly routine. Her two oldest children were struggling with class assignments and so the teachers, in line with popular educational theory, urged Ms. Davila to go home and read every night with her children. But the problem is Ms. Davila, a 23-year-old mother of three with another on the way, lives in a nearby homeless shelter where peace and quiet is a rarity and reading books is considered a luxury.

headline.main: The Challenge of Educating the Homeless

docs.abstract: Article on problems of educating homeless children in Connecticut; statistics are not kept since thousands of children are in shelters that do not receive state funds and thousands more live on streets or in overcrowded homes with friends or relatives; schools are learning to adapt to children in crisis who live in chaotic conditions at shelters; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: At 48, Wendy Wasserstein becomes a first-time mother-to-be and chronicles her triumph in The New Yorker. The pregnancies of Annette Bening and Jane Seymour make headlines. Other stories tell of women having babies using their own eggs, their husbands' sperm and surrogates' uteruses. The nonstop media parade of midlife women producing offspring is stunning. These stories are about the fortunate ones: they beat the odds.

headline.main: We Still Can't Stop The Biological Clock

docs.abstract: Zev Rosenwaks Op-Ed article says that despite all the publicity about women becoming pregnant in their 40's, there is no medical technique that will allow women to have their genetic children whenever they choose; says that for most women, fertility begins its inexorable decline when in the early 30's, plunges at 35, takes another precipitous drop at 39 and drops steeply and steadily thereafter (M)
